content.value_statement: Marketing pages often fail to convert visitors into customers due to unclear value propositions, weak CTAs, or poor visual hierarchy. This skill provides a systematic framework to analyze pages and deliver actionable CRO recommendations.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes marketing pages across 7 key dimensions including value proposition, headlines, CTAs, visual hierarchy, trust signals, objection handling, and friction points
Provides page-specific optimization frameworks for homepages, landing pages, pricing pages, feature pages, and blog posts
Delivers structured recommendations organized as quick wins, high-impact changes, test ideas, and copy alternatives
Identifies specific experiments to test based on page type and conversion goals
limitations: Does not access or analyze live websites directly - works from user descriptions or provided page content
Cannot run A/B tests or measure actual conversion performance
Does not provide quantitative analysis of existing conversion rates or traffic data
Relies on user-provided context about traffic sources and business goals

prompt_templates.title: Basic Page Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: This is a [homepage/landing page/pricing page/blog post] at [URL or description]. The primary goal is to get visitors to [desired action]. Traffic comes mainly from [traffic source]. Please analyze this page using your CRO framework and give me specific recommendations for improving conversions.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a quick analysis of a marketing page with basic context

prompt_templates.title: Detailed Page Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: I want you to do a comprehensive CRO audit of my [page type]. The page is located at [URL or provide description]. Current conversion rate is [X]%. Target audience is [description]. Main competitors are [list]. Please analyze: 1) Value proposition clarity, 2) Headline effectiveness, 3) CTA placement and copy, 4) Visual hierarchy, 5) Trust signals, 6) Objection handling, 7) Friction points. For each area, identify issues and suggest specific improvements.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a thorough multi-dimensional analysis

prompt_templates.title: Experiment Hypothesis Generation
prompt_templates.prompt: My [landing page/pricing page] is converting at [X]%. I want to run experiments to improve this. Based on best practices for this page type, what are the top 5 experiments I should consider? For each, explain the hypothesis, what to test, and how to measure success.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need A/B testing ideas and hypotheses

prompt_templates.title: Specific Element Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: The main CTA on my [page type] currently says [current copy] and converts at [X]%. The button color is [color]. The CTA appears [location]. Please suggest 5 alternative CTA button copy options with rationale for each, and explain how to prioritize testing them.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you want specific alternatives for CTAs, headlines, or other elements

output_examples.input: My SaaS pricing page isn't converting well. Current rate is 2%. Visitors come from organic search. The page has three plans with feature comparisons.
output_examples.output:
## Quick Wins (Implement Now)

1. **Add a "Most Popular" badge** to your middle plan - this anchors choice and reduces decision paralysis
2. **Highlight the annual discount toggle** - show 20% savings clearly when users toggle to annual
3. **Move social proof near pricing** - customer logos or testimonials close to pricing reduce price objections

## High-Impact Changes (Prioritize)

1. **Simplify the feature comparison** - users cannot scan 20+ features. Show only the top 5 differentiators per plan
2. **Add an ROI calculator** - let users see their value, not just your price
3. **Create a "which plan" guide** - FAQ answering common plan selection questions

## Test Ideas

1. Remove the lowest tier and test 2 plans vs 3 plans
2. Show enterprise pricing (even if "contact us") to anchor the upper range
3. Test "per month" vs "per user per month" language

output_examples.input: Our homepage conversion dropped after a redesign. The new design has more features shown upfront but conversions are down 30%.
output_examples.output:
## Analysis: Feature-First vs Benefit-First

Your redesign added features above the fold, which is likely causing the drop. Homepages need instant clarity on value, not a feature list.

## Quick Wins (Implement Now)

1. **Move features below the fold** - replace with 1-2 core value propositions
2. **Test a benefit-focused headline** - current may be too abstract. Try: "[Specific Outcome] in [Timeframe] without [Pain Point]"
3. **Add a single primary CTA above fold** - current may have competing actions

## High-Impact Changes (Prioritize)

1. **Create a new hero section** - leading with the #1 customer outcome, not features
2. **Implement sticky nav** with persistent CTA for users who scroll
3. **Add trust signals earlier** - logos or social proof in hero area

## Test Ideas

1. A/B test benefit-focused vs feature-focused hero
2. Test with vs without secondary navigation in hero

best_practices: Start analysis by identifying the single primary conversion goal - clarity on this prevents diluting recommendations across multiple objectives
Focus recommendations on above-the-fold elements first - changes here have highest impact on conversion rates
Always provide alternative copy suggestions with rationale - helps users understand the why behind recommendations
anti_patterns: Adding multiple CTAs on a single page - this creates choice overload and reduces conversions
Focusing on features instead of benefits - visitors care about outcomes, not specifications
Ignoring mobile experience in recommendations - many conversions happen on mobile devices

faq.question: What information should I provide for the best page analysis?
faq.answer: Provide the page URL, page type, primary conversion goal, traffic source, and current conversion rate. Any additional context about user research, heatmaps, or what you have already tried helps deliver more relevant recommendations.

faq.question: Does this skill access my website directly?
faq.answer: No. This skill analyzes pages based on your descriptions or provided content. It does not crawl websites, access analytics, or run any automated tests on your pages.

faq.question: How is this different from a general copywriting skill?
faq.answer: This skill focuses specifically on conversion optimization - analyzing existing pages for conversion barriers and providing structured recommendations. Copywriting skills help write new content from scratch. This skill evaluates and improves existing marketing pages systematically.

faq.question: Can this help with A/B testing setup?
faq.answer: This skill generates test hypotheses and specific alternatives to test, but it does not set up or run A/B tests. Pair this with an A/B testing skill to implement the recommended experiments.

faq.question: What page types does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill covers homepages, landing pages, pricing pages, feature pages, blog posts with CTAs, demo request pages, and resource/library pages. It also references related skills for signup flows, forms, and popups.

faq.question: How do I measure if recommendations work?
faq.answer: Track your primary conversion metric before and after implementing changes. Run changes as A/B tests when possible. Focus on statistically significant results over at least one full business cycle. Common metrics include conversion rate, click-through rate, and goal completions.
